chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Any reform should make presidential elections feel fair to voters in every state while keeping the process transparent, constitutional, and easy to verify. A balanced path is to keep the Electoral College but replace winner-take-all with a uniform method that awards electors in proportion to each candidate’s statewide vote, alongside national baseline rules for voter access, secure ballot handling, post‑election audits, and automatic recounts in close margins. If states cannot agree on proportional allocation, the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact can be a fallback once it has durable participation and clear auditability safeguards.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Presidential elections should reward broad, cross‑regional support while making every voter feel their ballot matters—not just those in a few swing states—and the rules should be clear, transparent, and easy to audit. A practical consensus reform is to keep the state-run framework but end winner‑take‑all by allocating electors proportionally nationwide (with the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a measured backstop if it reaches a durable threshold). Pair this with uniform national baseline standards for ballot access, counting, certification deadlines, post‑election audits, and automatic recount triggers so close outcomes are verifiable and widely accepted.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Presidential elections should reflect the national popular will while still valuing the states’ role and ensuring rural and smaller communities aren’t ignored. A practical, trust-building reform is to keep state administration but end winner-take-all by requiring proportional (or district-based) allocation of electors, with the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as an optional bridge once it reaches a stable threshold. Pair this with clear, nationwide baseline rules for voter access, ballot design, certification timelines, post‑election audits, and automatic recount triggers so results are easy to verify and broadly accepted.
